content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and pleasant to practice!

Very nice puzzle.
Just 3 small suggestions:
1. The sentence "There are three positive integers, called triads" sounds a bit ambiguous to me (Is there only one triad?), so maybe replace it with something like "A set of three positive integers is called a triad"
2. Looking at other puzzles, it seems like the standard input and output format is space separated, not comma separated. I don't know if you want to change this at this stage, maybe a suggestion for future puzzles.
3. Only IDE test 8 and none of the validators assume that triads can contain duplicate integers, meaning that a solution that assumes triads only contain unique integers can still pass all the validators, but not all the IDE tests. If this is intended, I suggest replacing IDE test 8; if this is not intended, a validator testing this behavior should be added. As others have already noted, stating this more explicitly in the statement would be nice.
Good work! I would approve it if I could.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good for understanding combinations for set of numbers and coding a solution for it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i like that you consider all possible combinations of triad sums in your test and validator cases
It's a little ambiguous if the triad numbers need to be distinct.  I believe it only makes a difference for 1,2,3 in your tests but it should be specified.

Goal
* Please delete "from a given list L".

* Do you think it's necessary to specify that the triads always consist of unique integers? For example, consider the case when the input is 1,2,3. The answer will be different when the uniqueness condition is imposed from that when it isn't.

Or it may also be the other way round: the triads do not have to consist of unique integers. In that case, please also specify that in the statement and add a pair of cases similar to 1,2,3.

Input
* Please add "[[L]]" after "a sorted subset".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Cover picture
* Suggest to add a cover picture for this puzzle. (P.S. also this puzzle: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1156146d442abd1af9d939579c1417e72dfe3e ).

Thanks.
thank you! i hope it's fine now

do you mean start with something like: "There are three not necessarily distinct positive integers, called triads"?

idk, nowhere say distinct numbers, then we could assume the numbers could be the same.

for me both cases are good

Test cases work for distinct and none distinct numbers in my code.
For the test case [1, 2, 3] there are always "many" solutions if you select 1 and 2 for the first two numbers. The third number can be anything and not used at all.

Hmmm, it seems that 1,2,3 is the only case where counting triads with duplicate numbers or not makes a difference to the output. Maybe enforcing the rule that triads must consist of unique numbers will make the puzzle slightly more interesting? Other than that, I don't have any other comments for the time being.
